Dear Shawna Henry:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 7/8/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:

• (f) A record of any convictions other than
minor traffic violations from either of the
following entities:
• (ii) From an entity accessing either
Michigan state police records or
equivalent state, Canadian
provincial, or other country law
enforcement agency where the
person usually resides or has
resided in the previous 5 years.
Three of eighteen employee/intern/volunteer individual personal files reviewed did
not have documentation of the required criminal history check. This involved two
volunteer files and one intern file. The two volunteer files reviewed had the
criminal history check completed after the start date of their action at the facility.
The intern file was missing the criminal history check documentation.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
One of eighteen employee/intern/volunteer individual personal files reviewed did
not have documentation of the Central Registry being completed on one of the
intern staff.

CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s
performance annually thereafter.
Two of thirteen employee files reviewed did not have documentation of the
required written evaluation in the file. One file had the evaluation due the day of
this inspection and the second file’s evaluation was due 5/20/24, which was 49
days from the date of this inspection.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers
• (1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and volunteer
who has contact with residents 4 or more hours
per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is
free from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom
from communicable tuberculosis shall be verified
within the 1 year period before employment and
shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the
current verification.
Two of eighteen employee/intern/volunteer individual personal files reviewed did
not have documentation of the TB test being completed prior to beginning
employment/work at the facility. This involves two volunteers with documentation
of the TB test taking place after hire.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:

• The Environmental inspection resulted in an A rating, however noted the wall
behind the main kitchen sink needs to be repaired and repainted.
• The Fire inspection resulted in an A rating, however noted any combustible
storage items from the corridors and means of egress need to be relocated to
a fire rated storage room or closet. The upright freezer must also be removed
from the stairway.
• The financial audit was not approved at this time, however moving forward the
facility needs to ensure that the financial audit is completed on an annual basis
and provided during the annual licensing inspections.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was required or requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: At the
time of this inspection (7/8/24) the CAP for 2024SIC0001417 had just been
approved on 6/29/24, therefore the facility is still in the very early stages of
following through with the action steps. During the next quarter unannounced visit
to the facility, each action step is expected to have some action being documented
as taking place.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment begins with identifying the special
investigation (2024SIC0001417) in which two violations (400.4127 and 722.120)

were found. At the time of this inspection, the CAP for this special investigation
has yet to be approved. This report also identified the need for electronic case
record keeping as a need and something the facility is in the process of
developing. The issue of unplanned discharges is addressed and most of these
discharges involved the older youth (16+), and in most cases these youth found
alternative placements and in most cases the parent or guardian approves of this
placement change as long as they are not returning home. The Chief Administrator
addresses the action step of Shelter Team meetings every other week to address
issues that might arise with a goal of developing better communication and
oversite of the operations of the facility. The facility is in the process of
accreditation which will help in the development of a solid program.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed all reported strong support from the administration. They are
receiving training that is helping them provide best practice for the youth in their
care. Staff also reported having staff meetings to ensure that services were
appropriate and consistent in dealing with the youth.
One of the two youth at the facility was interviewed. The youth not interviewed
refused to be interviewed and was leaving the facility during this inspection. The
youth interviewed reported feeling safe and well cared for at the facility and by
staff. The youth reported staff are attentive to his needs and will spend time talking
with him.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a two-story older building, and the facility is located on the ground floor.
The facility is well maintained and clean. There were no compliance issues found
and the furnishing were all appropriate.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
